transcripts.text: You really need to stop this superiority complex nonsense about human rights.  You think you are the only ones who respect human rights or others.  it's about violating human rights.  No.  We've fought for human rights and freedoms of our people much better and more than anyone, including you people who keep talking about this nonsense.  Where we have taken our country from and where it is now speaks for itself.  The rest of the story just comes from this complex.  These two worlds where there are people who know everything about human rights and all kinds of things, and another world where people are just people who don't know.  But these are our human rights.  When we respect the things we respect in our countries, It's not for you.  It's not for anybody.  It's for ourselves.  Is it not universal?  Yes, it is universal, but you don't sit there.  If it is universal and you believe it, then you don't become the judge yourself.  You don't start telling the others what to do, what they should not do, or that what they are doing is not to your satisfaction.  Who are you?
I'm not sure if we're talking about me personally.

Well, you are the one actually raising these questions.  So I think you better interpret it properly so that it is well understood.  I could see you asking questions in a manner that you want to influence the ones listening to us.  but that's not correct.
Okay.  I'm raising it once again in the context of the United Nations Development Goals.
No, United Nations is us.  You see, United Nations is not something alien somewhere else.
It's actually us.
We participate.
And the framework for this entire development conversation.

And by the way, I had been leading the Millennium Development Goals before Sustainable Development Goals.  I was the co-chair of that with other leaders and some of the leaders in Europe.  So you don't turn around, it's like you want...
So you believe that there should be scrutiny on human rights in Europe, in Africa, in all countries?
No, I believe that you shouldn't be there belittling Africans or leaders of Africa who are trying to...
Oh, no, but the conversation about migration is a real conversation about human rights.  So you believe that there are valid human rights concerns to be taken into account in this conversation?
Even in Europe, not in Africa.
Not in Africa?
In Europe, not only in Africa.  Of course.  Yes.

A judge somewhere in rural areas of France, one of the village judges somewhere, decides that he is going to indict leaders in Rwanda.  and talks about all kinds of things that happened in Rwanda and, you know, blames Rwandans for... At the same time, there is a bad history between us where actually during the genocide there are many things that happened that involved some people from France.  So now instead of actually having a case against France, a judge in France indicts the leaders of a country military leaders, political leaders, a whole list of about close to 20.  And they want to indict them to France to be tried for things that they say they did which are also completely fabricated.  But because of that bad history we have had, they wanted to do that and we said, This is not  possible.".  He said, if you are doing that and they called it universal jurisdiction that give the powers to these judges.  and he said, okay, if actually your judges have powers to do that, to indict people in Rwanda or elsewhere and take them to the courts in France, if it is universal then
our judges should have

the authority to actually indict your people and bring them to the courts of law.  So the question therefore was, how does it become universal when it is just one way?  And we have said, no way.  You are not going to try anybody from here unless we try those who have cases against actually that we are committed here.  In fact, the people they want to try in Rwanda even are not said to have committed crimes in France.  They are accusing them of committing crimes in Rwanda.  So how about those of your country that actually committed crimes in my own country that you don't allow you to try?
BBC is supposed to be, well, the standard of freedom of speech.  But all they do is politics.
They belittle people.  We are not people to be belittled at all.
They are no better than anybody.

We have fought for our freedoms right from childhood, some of us.  These people who just run around cannot, you know, they, of course, in their culture, they are not humble.  They think they are better than everybody else.  Well, it's not God-given.  God created us equal.  For these are the gods who want us to bow to them.  In Rwanda, they are in the wrong place.
But you can't belittle a people.

Well, you can attempt to attack me, to do whatever you want, me as a person, but a people, the Rwandans, to want to size them up and think you can turn them into nothing.  It's the wrong thing, but it's also very difficult because we cannot accept it.
